title: Ticket #7501: Add new Python-based test framework
description:
Yes, we already have a Python-based test framework: #6613 . Confusingly, it is named pytest. No relation to the pytest mentioned later.

However, we keep running into problems with it for (in my opinion) one main reason: it is not backed by a real Python test framework, so we keep needing to reinvent the wheel to deal with problems like #7451

To address this core problem, I've been prototyping a new test framework at https://github.com/JoshKarpel/pytest-condor which is backed by pytest, a venerable Python test framework (https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/). It handles test execution, reporting, output capture, and provides a convenient way to specify test setup and dependencies, including ways to parameterize tests.

The new framework has two main components:

  1. ornithology, a Python library for
    1. managing the lifecycle of a personal Condor
    2. executing HTCondor command-line programs (and parsing their results into Python data structures where appropriate)
    3. inspecting the state of the personal Condor via the job queue log, daemon log files, and job event logs
    4. providing "assertion helpers" that abstract away common conditions we need to test, like "are these things in the right order?".
  2. A conftest.py file (a pytest configuration file) that uses ornithology to provide basic building blocks for writing HTCondor tests with pytest.

ornithology should not be aware of pytest, such that ornithology could (in principle) be re-used with some other test runner or for entirely different purposes.

Goals:

  1. The control flow of the test should be clear from reading the test file itself (i.e., you should not have to follow a mess of callbacks to figure out what the test does).
  2. We should focus on building re-usable components and factoring common code out into the framework itself (assertion helpers, for example).
  3. We should document how the test framework itself works, possibly even with a full Read the Docs website.
  4. You shouldn't need to know Python deeply to "read" a test, and hopefully as little as possible to write a test. This is doubly true for test output on failure: you may need to know Condor-isms to interpret it, but you shouldn't need to know Python-isms.

Milestones:

  1. Get the new framework running in nightly builds (teach run_test.pl to run them; add them to the list of tests to run; make sure Metronome understands their output).
  2. Teach the team to use the new framework and start writing new tests using it.
  3. Convert old tests, especially ones we don't trust, to the new framework. Another good target would be the Python bindings tests.
  4. (Optional) Flip the script: make pytest the overall test runner (it would use run_test.pl to run any leftover old tests). We can argue about this in the future :)

This is a tracking ticket for the overall effort; extra dependent tickets may be spawned off for discrete tasks.
remarks:
2020-Feb-11 11:21:22 by tim:
I'd like to use this framework with binaries installed from packages. Let me know if that would be a possibility.

2020-Feb-11 11:34:12 by tlmiller:
It seems like ornithology should certainly be able to manage a Condor just given its $CONDOR_CONFIG, so ornithology should be agnostic as the source of the binaries.

Even if we want to run tests as root, we might not want to use /etc/condor/condor_config unmodified, because testing a live pool is probably not going to work, much less be helpful. So I guess ornithology should know how to use binary and library paths from one config (the system one) but point the logs and spool (etc) at some other place.

2020-Feb-11 12:30:09 by karpel:
ornithology assembles configs in a series of layers, based on the assumption that HTCondor has been installed on the system already.

  1. the output of condor_config_val -write:up (does this work on not-unix?)
  2. A hand-written "base config" that sets up roles and the locations of directories (in particular, the personal condor lives entirely in a test directory that the framework sets up): https://github.com/JoshKarpel/pytest-condor/blob/master/ornithology/condor.py#L179
  3. A hand-written "sane test config" https://github.com/JoshKarpel/pytest-condor/blob/master/ornithology/condor.py#L34
  4. config provided by the user as part of the test setup (i.e., it lives in the test file itself)

All of that gets merged together and printed as a single file in the test directory.

Commands are run in the system shell with CONDOR_CONFIG set to point to the config file generated above. Since I don't modify the system-config-set paths to executables or libraries, I believe it does the thing tlmiller desires.

(In fact, the only way this has ever been run so far is against installs via system package managers :)

2020-Feb-11 13:31:30 by tlmiller:
That looks very good to me.

2020-Feb-17 11:05:58 by coatsworth:
Hi all, I'm on board with torpedoing the previous Python testing framework in #6613 and moving forward with this. Having something backed by a proper, mature framework would obviously be hugely beneficial.

Josh, what is the current status of your new implementation? What's involved with getting it integrated into the master branch and ready to use? Something I think we should do immediately is rewrite the old tests that were based on the previous framework. With the previous framework, we found that new tests often brought new requirements that forced big changes in the API. Now that we actually have a handful of Python tests, I think we should convert them immediately to make sure they play nicely with this new framework.

2020-Feb-17 11:45:15 by karpel:
I'm currently working on batlab integration on a branch and doing workspace builds. I'm hoping that I'll get it working today!

I like the idea of targeting our existing Python tests first.

2020-Feb-19 15:18:01 by karpel:
I've just pushed a commit to branch V8_9-gt7501-branch with (hopefully) working batlab/metronome integration.

We should not merge into master yet because the tests only run on the CentOS7 batlab execute machines, because

  1. only those machines have Python 3 and pytest installed
  2. we do not have good support for cross-platform ancillary test files (like CMR monitor scripts) yet

Next steps on our end: convert existing Python tests, improving ornithology as we go. Make the tests run on all supported platforms.

Next steps for infrastructure: get Python 3 and pytest installed on all batlab execute machines.

NB: one of the new tests, test_concurrency_limits, consistently fails. I think this is an actual bug in HTCondor, not the test. Will presumably be easier to fix once we get the new tests working on master.

2020-Jun-11 04:44:13 by tlmiller:
A spreadsheet of test conversion work. Please update with what you know about and correct the mistakes I've inevitably introduced. "Complete" for this table means "the original test file(s) are now superfluous and can be deleted once the new test actually passes in BaTLab."

2020-Aug-25 18:33:02 by tlmiller:
This branch has been merged into master because of demand for a way to write new tests that didn't suck, but the work is not done; following up in #7811.
